Award.AwardTitle: Earth Resources Engineering Workshop; Washington, DC; October 5-6, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A one-day Workshop will be held October 6, 2015, at the National Academy of Sciences, Washington, DC. A primary goal is to develop a dialog between representatives of government and the Earth Resources Engineering Section of the National Academy of Engineering with respect to Research and Education in Subsurface Engineering. The discussion will focus primarily on two topics: 1) public fear that hydraulic fracturing may trigger damaging earthquakes, and 2) the future of mining and rock mechanics research and education. Used with great success in the petroleum industry since the 1940s, hydraulic fracturing is a key element of several engineering initiatives such as geothermal energy, underground storage of carbon dioxide, and disposal of wastewater from drilling. The workshop will explore the factors that influence the triggering of earthquakes by hydraulic fracturing, and the research that is needed to develop sound guidelines for the safe application of this technology. Minerals are the essential foundation of national economies in the United States and other developed nations, and are of vital importance to national security. Research to develop improved safety and efficiency is now critical as mines become deeper and challenges of safety, economics and environmental concerns rise. In decline at US universities for several decades, Mining Engineering is now close to being eliminated as an accredited engineering major. The workshop will seek to identify a realistic path forward for the U.S. to maintain mining engineering expertise.

The past several decades have seen numerous suggestions that the subsurface may provide solutions to a number of important national problems. The geothermal energy resources of hot rock at depths of the order of 5-6 km are enormous, provided a network of interconnected fractures can be created and fluids circulated to extract the heat economically. This requires understanding of coupled thermo-hydro-mechanical-chemical (THMC) processes and observation of the initiation, extension, and adaptive control of the fracture network. Essentially the same borehole technology will be needed for other uses of the subsurface, such as CO2 sequestration, disposal of drill wastewater, borehole mining. All these uses require a better appreciation of how the local geology and tectonic/gravitational force environment affects the potential for stimulation of damaging earthquakes. A significantly more detailed understanding of the engineering behavior of rock at depth is needed than currently available. This workshop will identify research needs to address these problems, while informing the broader engineering community of the potential impact of rock mechanics research on engineering grand challenges. The workshop will also address the problems related to the diminishing number of U.S. universities that offer a degree in mining engineering and courses in rock mechanics. With the increasing importance of rock mechanics in the solution of many critical problems, it is essential that the U.S. produce more, rather than fewer, engineers trained in this discipline. The workshop will explore potential strategies for addressing this issue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

The term ‘Earth Resources Engineering’ (ERE)was adopted by the National Academy of Engineering in 2006, replacing the designation ‘Petroleum, Mining and Geological Engineering’ used since the foundation of NAE in 1966.  The change was in recognition of the increasing use of the rock subsurface for non- extractive uses (e.g. radioactive waste isolation). The 2015 Symposium was the first event at which the three main ‘elements’ of ERE met to hear and discuss cross –disciplinary challenges. All three disciplines confront a very complex system - a variety of rock types, subject to changing forces over many millions and billions of years, that continues to evolve. Engineering disturbance of the existing equilibrium in the rock can lead to unanticipated consequences. In some respects, Earth Resources Engineering is more comparable to the practice of Medicine than to other engineering disciplines, where the behavior of the material involved is more predictable. The advent of powerful computers offers hope for the development of improved design procedures in ERE, but there is need for a concerted, continuing dialog between all sectors of ERE to stimulate this development.  The Symposium was recognized as an important step towards this end.

Broader Impacts.

Of the three main professional fields comprising ERE, Petroleum has a long tradition of industrial R&D; the US Geological Survey conducts R&D in Geological Engineering, especially with respect to groundwater- and aquifer depletion. The Mining industry has no tradition of ‘in-house’ mining R&D.[1] Recent efforts by some global companies (Rio Tinto; BHP Billiton;..) to support  R&D at universities were terminated over the last three years due to adverse economic conditions. Government programs, with 50:50 matching of industry support to university R&D are available in Australia and Canada –not in the US. A 14 month supply of oil is maintained in the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve in the event of interruption of imports. There is no comparable protection for the nation against any interruption of critically important minerals. The dependence of Society on minerals is well illustrated by the two-minute YouTube video Is Mining Important by Prof, Ken. J. Reid, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JXoQQB0_3SM

 In a March 2016 report to Congress, Dr. John P. Holdren, Assistant to President (Obama) for Science and Technology noted

“A consistent approach for making assessments across a broad range of minerals and providing early warning of potential supply vulnerabilities is important to U.S. economic and national security. Critical minerals are essential to a wide range of leading technologies, ranging from aircraft and automotive components to electronics and telecommunications devices, and from displays to photovoltaics.”

One effective option to reduce such vulnerabilities is for the US to be in the technological forefront of subsurface engineering. Technological developments resulting from US Outer Space exploration and related advances have potential for application to Inner (i.e. Subsurface) Space. The US should not miss this opportunity. “Knowledge is Power.” [2]

The recent announcement, by Chinese President Li, of the ‘New Silk Road’ OBOR initiative  http://www.nbcnews.com/news/china/belt-road-initiative-china-plans-1-trillion-new-silk-road-n757756   will involve considerable engineering of rock in situ - and associated R&D.  This will present a major challenge to researchers in the US striving to be in the forefront.

 


[1] There is a tradition of R&D in mineral processing and refining i.e. on the extracted minerals –removed from the in situ environment.      

[2] Attributed to Sir Francis Bacon (1597)  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientia_potentia_est
